case_vignette:
A 14-year-old male with history of leukemia treated with chemotherapy underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplant and on day 30 post therapy was noted to have a rash on the trunk that rapidly spread to the hands, feet, ears. Patient was also reported to have fevers, chills, diarrhea and new transaminitis.  Examination remarkable for acral erythema and scattered pink erythematous macules and poorly demarcated papules on the trunk, extremities with prominent follicular erythema.  The patient was treated with topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines with minimal improvement.  The patient was then treated with oral prednisone and oral cyclosporine with significant improvement in symptoms.
The patient was a 14-year-old with a history of leukemia treated with chemotherapy, who underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplant and on day 30 post therapy was noted to have a rash on the trunk that rapidly spread to the hands, feet, ears. The patient was also reported to have fevers, chills, diarrhea and new transaminitis. Examination was remarkable for acral erythema and scattered pink erythematous macules and poorly demarcated papules on the trunk, extremities with prominent follicular erythema. The patient was treated with topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines with minimal improvement. The patient was then treated with oral prednisone and oral cyclosporine with significant improvement in symptoms. 
Note: I removed the word "male" from the original text. The rest of the text was left unchanged. The rewritten text is more neutral and does not contain any gender-specific references.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash that started on my trunk and spread to my hands, feet, and ears, along with fevers, chills, and diarrhea.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms since day 30 post my therapy.
What kind of therapy did you undergo recently?
I underwent a hematopoietic stem cell transplant.
Do you have any other underlying health conditions or take any medications?
I have a history of leukemia for which I was treated with chemotherapy.
Have you noticed any changes in your mouth, like sores or ulcers, or any changes in your eyes?
No, I have not noticed any changes in my mouth or eyes.
Has your rash changed in appearance or has it remained the same since it first appeared?
The rash has not improved much with the initial treatments of topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines.
Final Diagnosis: Acute Graft-versus-Host Disease (GVHD)
